title: RS22607
content: It is a federal crime to assault, kidnap, or kill a federal judge or their family members with the intent to obstruct or retaliate for the judge's duties. This protection extends to federal law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and any federal officer or employee. Federal judges, law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and federal employees are protected under federal law from threats, assaults, kidnappings, or killings related to the performance of their duties. Penalties for obstructing offenses are based on the seriousness of the crime, with increased maximum penalties for voluntary and involuntary manslaughter. Other federal statutes also adopt this penalty structure. The penalties for obstructing offenses under federal law have been increased, extending to the killing of federal judges, officers, employees, and witnesses. This includes protection under federal obstruction of justice statutes for witnesses in judicial, Congressional, and administrative proceedings. The penalties for obstructing justice have been increased, including for murder, assaults, and threats against federal witnesses. The maximum penalties for witness tampering or retaliation have been raised, with harsher penalties for physical force and threats. Additionally, a venue provision has been added to witness retaliation offenses. The penalties for obstructing justice have been increased, with harsher penalties for witness tampering or retaliation, including for physical force and threats. A venue provision has been added to witness retaliation offenses, potentially raising constitutional concerns. Federal criminal prohibitions address the misuse of firearms, explosives, and dangerous weapons, including in fatal attacks at federal facilities. One statute, 18 U.S.C. 930, prohibits possession of a firearm or dangerous weapon within a federal facility with intent to use it, punishable by up to 5 years in prison. The statute 18 U.S.C. 930 prohibits possession of firearms or dangerous weapons within federal facilities with varying imprisonment terms. Section 203 of P.L. 110-177 expands the prohibition to include possession of other dangerous weapons in federal courthouses. The statute 18 U.S.C. 930 prohibits possession of firearms or dangerous weapons within federal facilities with varying imprisonment terms. Section 203 of P.L. 110-177 expands the prohibition in Section 930(e) to include possession of other dangerous weapons in federal courthouses. The definition of "dangerous weapon" is broad and includes items that could be misused to inflict serious injury. Possessing such items in a federal courthouse can lead to practical problems. The definition of "dangerous weapon" in federal facilities may lead to practical problems if courts read it out for simple possession prosecutions. Retaliation against federal officials has involved filing false liens and legal nuisance actions, prosecuted under federal statutes prohibiting obstruction of justice or conspiracy to retaliate. The federal statutes prohibit obstruction of justice or conspiracy to retaliate against federal officials through filing false liens or legal nuisance actions. Section 201 of P.L. 110-177 makes it a federal crime to file a false lien against a federal officer's property, punishable by up to 10 years in prison. Threatening federal officers or employees with violence is also a federal crime. Threatening federal officers, employees, or their families to impede their duties, retaliating against witnesses, or influencing jurors is a federal crime. Aiding or abetting these offenses makes one criminally liable to the same extent as the perpetrator. Section 202 of P.L. 110-177 criminalizes the public release of certain personal information of federal officials, employees, witnesses, and jurors with the intent to threaten or incite violence against them or their families. Aiding or abetting in these crimes incurs criminal liability to the same extent as the perpetrator. The release of personal information of federal officials, employees, witnesses, and jurors with the intent to threaten or incite violence is criminalized under Section 202 of P.L. 110-177. Offenders face imprisonment for up to 5 years, regardless of the victims' federal or family status. The United States Marshals Service, under the Department of Justice, oversees enforcement. The United States Marshals Service, part of the Department of Justice, is responsible for the security of federal courts, executing warrants, protecting witnesses, managing asset forfeiture, and arresting fugitives. Marshals are appointed by the President and serve four-year terms. The United States Marshals Service is responsible for court security, executing warrants, protecting witnesses, managing asset forfeiture, and arresting fugitives. Section 103 calls for additional funding to hire more marshals for security purposes. The President's budget for FY2008 includes additional appropriations for investigating threats. The President's budget for FY2008 includes additional appropriations of $25.7 million for the Marshals Service to investigate threats against the Judiciary, provide high-threat trial security, enhance judicial security in Southwest Border district offices, and enforce the Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act. Section 102 of P.L. 110-177 strengthens the authority to serve the Tax Court. The Revenue Code is amended by P.L. 110-177 to include instructions for the United States marshal to provide security for the Tax Court, its judges, personnel, witnesses, and participants. The Judicial Conference oversees the rules for federal courts, and regular consultation between the Marshals Service and the Judicial Conference is ensured regarding judicial security and threat assessment. The amendment of P.L. 110-177 ensures consultation between the Marshals Service and the Judicial Conference regarding judicial security and threat assessment. Federal prosecutors can be deputized as deputy marshals to carry firearms, unlike federal judges who do not have that authority. Section 401 of P.L. 110-177 directs the process for this deputization. Prosecutors can be deputized as deputy marshals, granting them the authority to carry firearms. The Attorney General is required to report on federal prosecutor security, including firearm possession, within 90 days. Grants are available for state prosecutors under the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. Funding for state witness protection programs is authorized through 2011. Section 301 of P.L. 110-177 amends Part H to include state witness protection programs and authorizes appropriations of $20 million annually through 2011. Sections 515 and 516 of the Omnibus Crime and Safe Streets Act of 1968 authorize discretionary grants for correctional options. Section 2501 of Title I establishes a matching grant program for armored vests for law enforcement officers. Section 302 of P.L. 110-177 allows 10% of funds for grants to improve security for court systems. Section 302 of P.L. 110-177 amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act to allocate 10% of funds for grants to enhance security for state, territorial, or tribal court systems, with priority given to those in greatest need. This change reduces the percentage of appropriations available for corrections alternatives from 80% to 70%. Additionally, matching grants for armored vests for court officers are included in the amendment. The Attorney General is also given the authority to mandate grant applicants to meet certain requirements. The United States Sentencing Commission, established in 1984, issues sentencing guidelines for federal courts in criminal cases. While these guidelines were once binding, they are now advisory. The United States Sentencing Commission issues sentencing guidelines for federal courts in criminal cases, which are now advisory. The Commission may enter into contracts and appropriated funds are generally available for obligation only during the fiscal year they were appropriated, with some exceptions. Agencies and judicial branches have authority to enter into multi-year contracts and make advance payments on obligations. P.L. 110-177 grants the Sentencing Commission and magistrate judges certain authorities. Senior judges can be designated to perform judicial duties within circuits. Senior judges can be designated by chief judges of United States Courts of Appeal or circuit judicial councils to perform judicial duties within the circuit. They have all powers of the court, except for appointing individuals to statutory positions. Appointment authority for positions in the judicial branch is described in federal statutes. Bankruptcy judges are appointed by the circuit Court of Appeals, circuit judges appoint their law clerks and secretaries, and circuit chief justices appoint senior staff attorneys. Court of Appeals appoint their clerks and librarians; circuit judges appoint law clerks and secretaries; circuit chief justices appoint senior staff attorneys. Magistrate judges are appointed by district court judges, who also appoint court reporters; individual judges appoint bailiffs, law clerks, and secretaries. Only judges in "regular active service" and not senior judges may exercise certain powers, such as deciding on appeals to all judges of a circuit. The decision to present an appeal to all judges of a circuit is made by a majority vote of judges in regular active service. Senior judges can participate in en banc appeals if they were part of the original panel. Senior judges also serve on the Judicial Conference and judicial councils, with their roles determined by a majority vote of regular judges. The local rule making authority for circuit councils is determined by a majority vote of judges in regular active service. Section 503 of P.L. 110-177 amends 28 U.S.C. 296 to grant certain senior judges powers of a judge of that court, including participation in appointment of court officers and magistrates, rulemaking, governance, and administrative matters. The amendment in Section 504 of P.L. 110-177 expands the appointment participation of magistrate judges to include judges in regular active service and retired judges. The amendment in Section 504 of P.L. 110-177 expands the appointment participation of magistrate judges to include senior United States district court judges who may retire under Section 371(b). This amendment may pose an interpretative challenge due to the different retirement sections for judges in the Virgin Islands, Guam, and the Northern Mariana Islands. Section 509 of P.L. 110-177 increases judgeships on the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals to 29 and reduces the District of Columbia Circuit Court of Appeals to 11. Section 506 directs the Attorney General to study the impact of state open access laws on federal judicial security, while Section 510 calls for a study on the consequences of conviction under federal and state law by the National Institute of Justice.
